text: Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ For patients with osteoporosis, supplementation with 500-1,200 mg of calcium and 400-800 IU vitamin D per day is recommended.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ Perform surgery for cases with nasal deformities of a nasal blockage type.

triples: nasal deformities of a nasal blockage type

text: Patients with osteoporosis @ For elderly patients with osteoporosis or elderly people with low bone mass and high risk of fractures, it is recommended to supplement calcium and vitamin D as one of the basic measures.

triples: elderly people with low bone mass

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ If pain is considered to be neuropathic in origin, treatment with a gabapentinoid (e.g. pregabalin or gabapentin), a tricyclic antidepressant (e.g. amitriptyline, nortriptyline or trimipramine) or a selective serotonin‐noradrenaline (known in the USA as norepinephrine) reuptake inhibitor (SNRI; e.g. duloxetine) is warranted

Patients with deep vein thrombosis @ For patients with central or mixed deep venous thrombosis in the acute stage, if their general condition is good, their expected survival is ≥1 year, and their bleeding risk is small, CDT can be the first choice.

triples: central or mixed deep venous thrombosis in the acute stage

text: Patients with hallux valgus @ For some elderly patients with osteoporosis or those unable to undergo other surgical treatments, Keller arthroplasty can be considered to relieve pain.

Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For patients who suffer from even mild symptoms simultaneously with or before pollen dispersal, start medication at the onset of symptoms. Administer second-generation antihistamine or mast cell stabilizer for symptoms of sneezing and rhinorrhea type. Administer leukotriene receptor antagonists, a prostaglandin D2/thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist, or a Th2 cytokine inhibitor for symptoms of nasal blockage type and those of combined type with nasal blockage as a chief complaint.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For cases with severe nasal mucosal swelling and severe pharyngeal and laryngeal symptoms at hospital visit, administer oral corticosteroids for up to 4-7 days.

patients with CKD @ For CKD stages 1-2 in diabetic patients, it is recommended to limit sodium intake to 2.3 g/day, but strict sodium restriction is not advised. For CKD stages 3-5 in non-diabetic patients, it is recommended to limit dietary sodium intake to less than 2.3 g/day.

triples: limit dietary sodium intake to less than 2.3 g/day

text: Patients with gastrinoma @ For patients without evident signs of metastasis, tumor resection should be pursued whenever feasible. In cases of metastatic tumors, the preferred chemotherapy for pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors is the combination of streptozocin with 5-fluorouracil or doxorubicin.
Patients with viral hepatitis @ For those with genotype 2, 3, 5 or 6 infection, glecaprevir/pibrentasvir for 12 weeks is  recommended.

Patients with malignant pleural effusion @ For patients with multiloculated malignant pleural effusion or inadequate drainage response to simple procedures, the recommendation is intrapleural injection of fibrinolytic agents such as urokinase or streptokinase to reduce pleural adhesions.

triples: inadequate drainage response to simple procedures

text: Patients with bronchiectasis @ The recent ERS guidelines conditionally recommended, with low quality of evidence, that inhaled antibiotics be considered in patients with chronic pseudomonas infection and a high exacerbation frequency

Patients with viral hepatitis @ Patients with advanced cirrhosis, on immunosuppression, or nonresponders to previous vaccination should be given a double-dose regimen (40 μg) of hepatitis B vaccine at standard intervals

Patients with atrial fibrillation @ Patients with atrial fibrillation: For patients with atrioventricular accessory pathway and hemodynamic instability, direct current cardioversion is the first choice; for patients with obvious hemodynamic abnormalities, propafenone, amiodarone or procainamide is used.
Patients with hematological disorders @ When patients with megaloblastic anemia receive folic acid and vitamin B12 supplementation; When iron deficiency anemia occurs, supplement with iron.

Patients with early cervical cancer @ For patients with early-stage cervical cancer who are younger, have no lymph node metastasis, and want to have children, fertility-sparing surgery should be performed.
CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ If a bacterial cause is excluded and no symptom improvement is observed after antibiotic therapy, referral to specialist care should be considered.

triples: no symptom improvement is observed after antibiotic therapy

text: Patients with levator ani syndrome @ During acute attacks, relief from pain can be achieved through anal gas and bowel movements, sitz baths, or mild analgesics. When symptoms are more severe, physical therapy is often effective.

Patients with primary liver cancer @ For patients with CNLC stage IIIa liver cancer, surgery is not the preferred initial option in the majority of cases. However, if the tumor is confined to half of the liver or the same side of the liver, surgical resection of the tumor can be considered.

triples: confined to half of the liver or the same side of the liver
surgery is not the preferred initial option

text: Patients with Pulmonary Alveolar Proteinosis @ Whole lung lavage is the first choice and effective treatment for patients with significant respiratory impairment.
Infantile cholestasis @ Liver transplantation is an effective therapeutic measure for end-stage liver disease resulting from infantile cholestasis.
Patient with gastric cancer @ EGC without lymph node metastasis can be a candidate for surgery or endoscopic therapy based on the depth of tumor invasion

Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction @ For patients with severe narrowing or distortion of the main pancreatic duct, attempting transpapillary stenting can be considered. Otherwise, the placement of a pancreatic stent via ERCP is used to treat main pancreatic duct strictures.

triples: Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction

text: Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ For patients presenting with erosive esophagitis, we recommend treatment with PPIs rather than H2RAs.
Patients with pancreatic cancer @ Choledochojejunostomy or hepaticojejunostomy could be performed for patients with unresectable tumors and biliary obstruction or expected biliary obstruction.
Patients with WD @ For patients with advanced liver disease or liver failure, liver transplantation may be necessary.
Children with recurrent respiratory tract infections @ Xiyanping injection is used for children over 2 years old; Reduning injection can be used for children over 3 years old.

triples: Children with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Children with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Children with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Children with recurrent respiratory tract infections

text: Patients with OSA @ For OSA patients with nocturnal blood pressure elevation exhibiting a reverse-dipper pattern, it is recommended to use angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers as antihypertensive medications. Beta-blockers and centrally acting antihypertensive drugs are not preferable in this case.

Patients with WD @ Penicillamine is suitable for WD patients with neurological or psychiatric symptoms and those allergic or intolerant to D-penicillamine. The initial dose for adults is 750 to 1,500 mg/d, and the pediatric dose is 20 mg/(kg·d).

bladder cancer patients @ For patients with muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC) who are not suitable candidates for or unwilling to undergo radical cystectomy, a comprehensive treatment approach with bladder preservation can be considered.

triples: not suitable candidates for radical cystectomy
comprehensive treatment approach with bladder preservation

text: Patients with autoimmune hepatitis @ Since bone marrow suppression can occur, azathioprine treatment is not recommended in patients with patients with severe leukopenia, severe thrombocytopenia, or homozygote mutation in the NUDT15 or TPMT gene.

Patients with liver cancer @ RFA treatment is suitable for CNLC stage Ia and some Ib stage liver cancers (i.e., the diameter of a single tumor is ≤5cm; or the maximum diameter of 2 to 3 tumors is ≤3cm), and it can achieve a curative effect. For a solitary tumor with a diameter of 3-7 cm or multiple tumors that cannot be surgically removed, a combination of Transarterial Chemoembolization (TACE) treatment can be considered.

triples: the diameter of a single tumor is ≤5cm
the maximum diameter of 2 to 3 tumors is ≤3cm
a solitary tumor with a diameter of 3-7 cm

text: Patients with malignant gastric obstruction @ For patients who are not suitable for endoscopic dilation or whose endoscopic dilation is ineffective, gastrostomy can be performed to relieve obstructive symptoms. Otherwise, gastrointestinal decompression can be performed by surgical or interventional radiological means.

Patients with candidiasis @ For patients who do not respond to conventional treatment with AmB-d or fluconazole, LFAmB, voriconazole is a reasonable treatment option, with voriconazole at a dose of 3-4 mg/kg twice daily.

triples: do not respond to conventional treatment

text: Patients with eosinophilic sinusitis @ In treating eosinophilic sinusitis in patients with aspirin intolerance, avoid using analgesics, antipyretics and antiinflammatory drugs.

heart failure patients @ For patients with acute heart failure or cardiogenic shock where pharmacological treatment is ineffective, short-term mechanical circulatory support may be considered. This includes percutaneous ventricular assist devices, extracorporeal life support (ECLS), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

Patients with liver failure @ Fresh frozen plasma and platelets should be administered when there is active bleeding or invasive procedures. However, in the absence of active bleeding or invasive procedures, routine administration of blood products to correct coagulation abnormalities is not recommended.

triples: in the absence of active bleeding or invasive procedures

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ In patients describing typical neuropathic pain symptoms (e.g. burning, shooting pain), or in any patient with persistent pain (>3 months), consider the possibility of neuropathic pain and treatment with appropriate anti-neuropathic medication strategies.

Patients with knee osteoarthritis @ It is important to clarify the appropriate indications for arthroscopic partial meniscectomy in patients with knee osteoarthritis in the study. This surgery is suitable for patients with mild to moderate knee osteoarthritis and MRI confirmed meniscus tears.

Patients with thrombocytopenia in cancer patients with liver injury @ For patients with tumor-associated thrombocytopenia and underlying liver disease, platelet transfusion may be considered in the event of bleeding.

triples: Patients with thrombocytopenia in cancer patients with liver injury
Patients with thrombocytopenia in cancer patients with liver injury

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ In patients with early‐stage disease who present with pain symptoms, regular paracetamol may be offered.
Patients with liver cancer @ For patients with liver cancer and bile duct tumor thrombus, simultaneous resection of the liver tumor and bile duct, aiming to achieve a chance for radical resection.

triples: simultaneous resection of the liver tumor
simultaneous resection of the bile duct

text: Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For symptoms of nasal blockage type, use a combination of leukotriene receptor antagonists or prostaglandin D2/thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist and nasal topical steroids. For symptoms of combined type, only the second generation vasoconstrictor nasal spray is added for 7-10 days at the beginning of treatment as required.
Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ For those who are intolerant or contraindicated, etidronate sodium, risedronate sodium and zoledronate sodium can be used.

Patients with keloid @ For small scars, if there is significant congestion, initial treatment may involve pulsed dye laser therapy or the injection of anti-vascular drugs (such as triamcinolone) to reduce congestion. Subsequently, a combination of silicone preparations and topical medications is used to assist in preventing recurrence. In cases without noticeable congestion, a combination of drug injections until complete softening, along with silicone preparations, other topical medications, and compression therapy, is employed to prevent recurrence.

Patients with simple hallux valgus @ For patients with intermetatarsal angle (IMA) less than 13°, perform distal metatarsal osteotomy such as Chevron, Mitchell, etc. For those with IMA between 14° and 16°, use metatarsal neck osteotomy like Scarf. When IMA is greater than 16°, consider base osteotomy. In severe cases with IMA exceeding 20°, first metatarsophalangeal joint fusion is often recommended for correction.

Patients with AKI @ For patients with a long-term history of AKI, who require more than 90 days of renal replacement therapy before liver transplantation, who are over 60 years old, and have underlying chronic kidney disease or hereditary kidney disease, it is recommended to undergo combined liver kidney transplantation.

triples: rmore than 90 days of renal replacement therapy

text: Patients with non-invasive breast cancer @ For premenopausal females with LCIS, tamoxifen for 5 years is recommended after wide local excision. For postmenopausal females, tamoxifen or raloxifene may be given to lower the risk of breast cancer.

Patients with COPD @ For patients experiencing dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance, the recommended initial treatment is the combination of a Long-Acting Muscarinic Antagonist and a Long-Acting Beta-Agonist.
Patients with AIH @ Antiviral prophylaxis is recommended if AIH patients have a high or moderate risk of reactivation of CHB during immunosuppressive therapy.

triples: high or moderate risk of reactivation of CHB

text: Children with sinusitis @ For children with chronic sinusitis, adenoidectomy combined with sinus lavage is the preferred surgical treatment method.

Patients with keloid @ For inflammatory-type keloids, non-surgical treatment is still recommended for small keloids. For medium, large, or extremely large keloids, surgical treatment is generally advised. However, if there is no significant hypertrophic scarring in medium to large inflammatory-type keloids, non-surgical treatments, including drug injections, pulsed dye laser, silicone preparations, and topical medications, may also be considered.

triples: if there is no significant hypertrophic scarring

text: Patients with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy @ In patients with hepatic encephalopathy and altered mental function complicating liver cirrhosis, considering the clinical context, symptom improvement may be achieved through the use of opioid receptor antagonists, benzodiazepine receptor antagonists, or propofol.

triples: Patients with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy
Patients with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy
Patients with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy
Patients with cirrhosis and hepatic encephalopathy

text: Patients with SBP @ Patients with a Child-Pugh score ≥9, serum bilirubin levels ≥3 mg/dl, or impaired renal function, hyponatremia, and abdominal fluid protein below 15 g/L are recommended to use norfloxacin (400 mg/day) as primary prophylaxis.

Patients with compound thumb valgus @ If the IMA is mildly to moderately enlarged, Chevron-Youngswick surgery to dorsiflex the metatarsal head may be appropriate. For severe IMA enlargement, consider proximal metatarsal osteotomy to correct IMA, followed by fixation in a dorsiflexed position of the metatarsal head.

triples: IMA is mildly to moderately enlarged
Chevron-Youngswick surgery to dorsiflex the metatarsal head
proximal metatarsal osteotomy to correct IMA

text: frostbite patient @ For patients with severe trauma, other potential infectious sources, or symptoms of cellular dermatitis or sepsis, systemic antibiotics should be administered, either orally or intravenously.
Patients with alcoholic liver disease @ Liver transplantation should be considered in patients with severe alcoholic cirrhosis,  which in the early stage can improve survival.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Inpatients with complex strictures or a lack of apparent dilation effect during ERCP, a stent may be placed after successful stricture dilation.

triples: a lack of apparent dilation effect during ERCP

text: Patients with keloid @ In principle, conservative treatment is recommended for small scars. For small scars on the ear and small scars with infectious foci, surgical excision remains the primary treatment approach. Medium to large scars should undergo surgical intervention at an early stage. For extremely large scars, a comprehensive treatment approach involving surgical excision supplemented by skin grafts and flaps is recommended.

Patients with alcoholic liver disease @ In case of non-response to corticosteroids, highly selected patients should be considered for early liver transplantation. Patients that response to corticosteroid treatment have to continue corticosteroid treatment for 28 days
Patients with vascular gastrointestinal disease @ Mild and recurrent bleeding patients can undergo long-term iron supplementation therapy.

Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and low cardiac output in acute heart failure (AHF), if there is evidence of inadequate tissue perfusion such as hypotension, intravenous administration of positive inotropic agents is recommended to alleviate symptoms.

patients with MHD @ For MHD patients, recommend a caloric intake of 35 (kcal·kg)/(IBW·d). For patients aged 60 and above, with low activity levels and good nutritional status, the intake can be reduced to 30-35 (kcal·kg)/(IBW·d).

triples: the intake can be reduced to 30-35 (kcal·kg)/(IBW·d)

text: Patients with hepatolenticular degeneration @ For those with mild symptoms of fever and rash in an allergic reaction, oral administration of a low dose of prednisone (0.5 mg/(kg·d), continued for 2-3 days) may be considered.

triples: oral administration of a low dose

text: Patients with acute cholecystitis @ Conservative manage ment with fluids, analgesia and antibiotics is an option for people with mildly symptomatic acute cholecystitis

Patients with bronchiectasis @ Cystic fibrosis testing should be considered in patients with concomitant sinus disease, gastrointestinal or pancreatic abnormalities, male infertility and a family history of bronchiectasis.

Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia @ Transurethral incision of the prostate should be offered as an option for patients with prostates <=30g for the surgical treatment of LUTS/BPH. Prostatic urethral lift or robotic waterjet treatment should be considered as a treatment option for patients with BPH provided prostate volume 30-80g and verified absence of an obstructive middle lobe.

triples: verified absence of an obstructive middle lobe

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ Early use of medication targeting neuropathic pain should be considered for all patients who are refractory to initial treatments. If the patient has neuropathic pain, ensure a prompt referral to an MDT that includes pain specialists

Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ A trial of baclofen at a dosage of 5-20 mg three times a day can be considered in patients with objective documentation of continued symptomatic reflux despite optimal PPI therapy.
Patients with chronic sinusitis @ Medically resistant CRS might respond to appropriate sinonasal surgery.
Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with low blood pressure, direct intravenous infusion of rh-BNP at a rate of 0.0075 to 0.01 µg/(kg·min) can be used for maintenance.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ A therapeutic endoscopic intervention is indicated in symptomatic patients with relevant strictures.

Patients with WD @ Symptomatic individuals should initiate treatment with chelating agents, while asymptomatic patients or those entering maintenance therapy can be treated with either chelating agents or zinc supplements.
Infantile cholestasis @ Bile acids or ursodeoxycholic acid are suitable for children with defects in bile acid synthesis.
Patients with DILI @ Cases in which onset resembles acute hepatitis (acute onset) should be administered corticosteroid therapy.
Patients with liver cancer @ For HCV-related liver cancer, it is recommended to use direct-acting antivirals for antiviral treatment when HCV RNA is positive.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For symptoms of sneezing and rhinorrhea type, start treatment by the combination of second-generation antihistamine and nasal topical steroids.
Patients with renal tubular acidosis @ Potassium citrate replacement may be necessary for patients with hypokalemia, nephrolithiasis, or nephrocalcinosis.
Patients with NSCLC @ In patients with positive driver genes, molecular targeting drugs should be given priority in second-line treatment.

triples: In patients with positive driver genes

text: Patients with breast cancer @ For HER2-positive and triple-negative breast cancer patients, the indications for neoadjuvant therapy can be appropriately extended.

patients with CKD @ For CKD patients with blood potassium levels exceeding 6.0 mmol/L, the recommended daily potassium intake is 50-70 mmol. In cases where blood potassium levels are above 5.5 mmol/L in individuals with renal impairment, it is advisable to maintain a dietary potassium intake of less than 3 g/day.

triples: blood potassium levels are above 5.5 mmol/L
dietary potassium intake of less than 3 g/day

text: Patients with primary vasculitis@who have important organ involvement, in addition to glucocorticoids, should also take immunosuppressants as early as possible. Plasma exchange and immunoadsorption can be performed in acute phase and critically ill patients.

Patients with nongenital mucocutaneous candidiasis @ For mild disease, clotrimazole troches at a dosage of 10 mg 5 times daily; for moderate to severe disease, oral fluconazole at a dosage of 100-200 mg (3 mg/kg) daily for 7-14 days is recommended

triples: clotrimazole troches at a dosage of 10 mg

text: Patients with breast hyperplasia @ For individuals experiencing mild to moderate breast pain, psychological counseling and lifestyle changes are the primary interventions. In cases of persistent and severe breast pain, pharmacological treatment may be considered.
Patients with PVT @ For patients with chronic PVT, if there is thrombus extension to the mesenteric veins, anticoagulant therapy is recommended.

triples: thrombus extension to the mesenteric veins

text: Patients with chronic pancreatitis @ It is recommended that for early CP patients sensitive medications can be administered for 4 to 6 weeks as first-line treatment. The use of opioid medications is not recommended.

Patients with keloid @ For patients under the age of 16, treatment should follow the principles of managing pediatric keloids. The use of anti-tumor chemotherapy drugs and radiation therapy is generally not recommended.
Patients with CKD @ For CKD patients with HCV infection treated with DAA, it is recommended to use sofosbuvir/velpatasvir/voxilaprevir therapy.

patients with chronic interstitial nephritis @ If chronic renal failure occurs, conservative treatment without dialysis should be given to delay the progression of renal damage; if it has entered the end stage, renal replacement therapy should be performed.

Patients with AIH-PBC overlap syndrome @ UDCA treatment first and sequential addition of immunosuppressive drug can be considered for AIH-PBC overlap syndrome patients if the patient shows predominant features of PBC. Otherwise, combination treatment with UDCA with the immunosuppressive drug is preferred for AIH-PBC overlap syndrome.

Patients with liver damage @ Muscle tension and stiffness can be managed with medications such as tizanidine, baclofen, and cyclobenzaprine. For tremors, options include benzodiazepines, combination dopamine agonist medications, and others.

Patients with keloid @ For patients with widespread keloids, if there is localized infection, consideration may be given to the excision of the infected area. Otherwise, non-surgical treatment methods are generally recommended for such keloids. These methods may include silicone products, topical medications, laser therapy, cryotherapy, and compression therapy.

Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For conjunctivitis, add the following agents: oral histamine H1 antagonists, or intraocular histamine H1 antagonists, or intraocular disodium cromoglycate (or eye irrigation with physiological saline)

triples: or eye irrigation with physiological saline

text: Patients with SBP @ Empirical treatment for community-acquired mild to moderate spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) in patients is primarily recommended with a single agent from the third-generation cephalosporin class.
Patients with candidiasis @ Fluconazole is recommended for moderate-to-severe disease, and topical therapy with clotrimazole or nystatin is recommended for mild disease.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For mild symptoms, administer second-generation antihistamine or a mast cell stabilizer. If symptoms are exacerbated, concomitantly use nasal topical steroids early.

Patients with knee osteoarthritis @ Topical NSAIDs should be used with caution in certain health conditions such as stage 4-5 chronic kidney disease, coronary artery disease, and congestive heart failure. There is a risk for skin sensitivity.
Patients with autoimmune hepatitis @ MMF (1-2 g/day) is given with glucocorticoids for patients intolerant of AZA or who have incomplete first-line treatment.
Arteriovenous fistula patients @ For patients with congenital fistulas, vascular intervention is recommended; for acquired fistulas, surgical treatment is advised.

Patient with gastric cancer @And dissection of lower mediastinal nodes should be added for the tumor with its center above the EGJ. A transhiatal abdominal approach is recommended for distal esophageal invasion less than 3 cm.

triples: tumor with its center above the EGJ
distal esophageal invasion less than 3 cm

text: Pediatric epilepsy patients @ For patients with recurrent symptoms and insufficient efficacy with traditional Chinese medicine alone, a combination therapy approach involving Western medicine, acupuncture, and other modalities may be considered.

triples: insufficient efficacy with traditional Chinese medicine alone

text: Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ For elderly patients with osteoporosis, if liver and kidney diseases cause vitamin D hydroxylation to be blocked, it is recommended that active vitamin D be the first choice.

triples: vitamin D hydroxylation to be blocked

text: Patient with gastric cancer @ For local advanced gastric cancers, and EGC with lymph node metastasis, comprehensive treatments based on the surgery is recommended.
Patients with ventricular arrhythmias @ For non-sustained, asymptomatic ventricular arrhythmia patients, it is not recommended to use antiarrhythmic drugs other than beta-blockers.

Patients with ureteral stones @ Most patients with stones less than 0.4cm in diameter can pass by themselves. For patients with stones with a diameter of 0.6cm or less, drug-assisted stone removal is the first choice. For patients with stones larger than 1 cm in diameter, surgical intervention is the first choice.

triples: stones with a diameter of 0.6cm or less
stones larger than 1 cm in diameter

text: Patients with candidiasis @ For patients with endocarditis and other cardiovascular infections, higher daily doses of an echinocandin may be appropriate (e.g., caspofungin 50-150 mg/day, micafungin 100-150 mg/day, or anidulafungin 100-200 mg/day).

Patients with PVT @ For patients with high-risk varices and the need for anticoagulant therapy in PVT, it is recommended to use non-selective beta-blockers to prevent variceal bleeding. If the patient cannot tolerate non-selective beta-blockers or has contraindications, endoscopic variceal ligation is recommended to prevent variceal bleeding.

Patients with idiopathic inflammatory myopathies @ For individuals with moderate disease severity, oral prednisolone at a dose of 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (usually 40-60 mg, maximum 100 mg per day) is recommended. For those with more severe disease, intravenous methylprednisolone (250-500 mg in 2-3 doses on alternate days) can be used initially and then converted to oral prednisolone once disease severity has reduced.
Patients with hallux valgus @ For individuals with excessive softness, accompanied by ligament laxity or neuromuscular dysfunction, conservative treatment is recommended as the first choice.

Patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis @ General recommendations for patients suffering from cholestasis-associated pruritus include using emollients to pre vent dryness of skin, avoiding hot baths or showers.

Patients with breast cancer @ For patients with advanced breast cancer, if they have a low tumor burden and no signs of rapid progression, single-agent chemotherapy is the first choice, which can improve their quality of life.
Patients with HCV-GN @ For HCV-associated glomerulonephritis patients with stable renal function and/or non-nephrotic proteinuria, initiate treatment with a DAA regimen.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For persistent moderate/severe symptoms, nasal spray steroid medications are used.
Patients with candidiasis @ For refractory disease, itraconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, or AmB suspension is recommended.

Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @If pruritus occurs, cholestyramine can be used to relieve itching, approximately (4-16 g/day). Rifampicin (100-300 mg/day) is recommended for those who do not respond or are intolerant to cholestyramine.

Patients with deep vein thrombosis @ For patients with central or mixed deep venous thrombosis in the acute stage, when femoral bruising occurs, surgical thrombectomy or PMT, CDT and other treatments should be performed immediately.

Children with liver cancer @ For patients with unresectable tumors, the use of transcatheter arterial chemoembolization can be considered as a treatment option. For patients with resectable tumors, surgical resection of lung metastases can be considered.
Patients with acute kidney injury @ For patients with low blood pressure, vasopressors such as terlipressin or norepinephrine, in combination with albumin infusion, can be considered.

Patients with duodenal obstruction @ In patients with duodenal obstruction, gastrojejunostomy could be performed if the expected survival time is more than 3 months. Intraopetative radiotherapy, irreversible electroporation (nanoknife ablation) could also be taken to improve local tumor control rate and relieve pain.

triples: the expected survival time is more than 3 months

text: Children with rheumatic fever @ In case of carditis, glucocorticoids, such as prednisone, should be used early. Children without carditis can use nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as aspirin.

Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For sneezing and runny nose type symptoms, use a combination of nasal topical steroids and second-generation antihistamine. For symptoms of the nasal blockage type and those of combined type, add leukotriene receptor antagonists or a prostaglandin D2/thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist.
Patients with hepatic hydatid disease @ For patients for whom surgery cannot achieve a cure but who have complications such as biliary obstruction, palliative surgery can be considered.
Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections @ Acetaminophen or ibuprofen can be chosen for fever reduction in individuals with a body temperature exceeding 38.5°C.

triples: Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections

text: Patients with cirrhosis and ascites @ For patients with refractory or recurrent ascites in cirrhosis, the use of covered TIPS is recommended as a treatment option.

Patients with decompensated cirrhosis @ For patients with mild, moderate, or severe ascites, or those hospitalized due to worsening ascites or any complications of liver cirrhosis, diagnostic abdominal paracentesis is recommended.

Patients with compound thumb valgus @ For patients with mild to moderate increases in IMA and DMAA, Mitchell, Chevron-Gerbert with additional distal soft tissue correction, or Akin procedures can be considered. For severe cases, proximal osteotomy may be required to correct IMA, and distal osteotomy may be needed to correct DMAA.

triples: mild to moderate increases in IMA and DMAA

text: Patients with SAP @ For SAP patients presenting with acute respiratory failure, early oxygen therapy should be initiated. Non-invasive respiratory support may be considered as an early supportive measure. If the condition does not improve or worsens rapidly within a short period, invasive mechanical ventilation should be considered.
proteinuria patients @ ACEI drugs can easily cause dry cough. If the patient cannot tolerate ACEI drugs, ARB can be used instead.
Patients with CRC @ For patients with colorectal cancer (CRC), if there is the NRS2002 nutritional risk score ≥3 or if there is a PG-SGA malnutrition score ≥4, nutritional therapy is necessary.
Patients with NSCLC @ First-line EGFR-TKI treatment is recommended for stage IV NSCLC patients with EGFR-sensitive mutation.

Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ For patients with dry mouth and dysphagia, it is recommended to try over-the-counter saliva substitutes such as moisturizing mouthwashes and mouth spray. If the symptoms worsen, cholinergic agents such as pilocarpine or cevimeline are recommended to increase saliva secretion.

Patients with liver cancer @ Nucleoside analog antiviral treatment can control the underlying liver disease in patients with HBV-related liver cancer. For HCV-related liver cancer, direct-acting antiviral drugs can achieve sustained virological response.

Patients with acute pancreatitis@ Mild patients can be given oxygen by nasal cannula or mask. When acute lung injury or respiratory distress occurs, positive pressure mechanical ventilation should be provided, the amount of fluid replacement should be adjusted based on parameters such as urine output, blood pressure, and arterial blood pH, and diuretics should be used appropriately.

triples: be given oxygen by nasal cannula or mask

text: Patients with CKD @ For CKD patients with acute hepatitis C, it is recommended to use sofosbuvir/velpatasvir for a 12-week treatment course.
obese patients @ Obese patients with gout can consider adopting the Mediterranean diet or the DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diet.

triples: DASH (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) diet.

text: Patients with ascites @ Appropriate sodium restriction is recommended for patients with moderate uncomplicated ascites, and long-term bed rest is not recommended.

triples: long-term bed rest is not recommended

text: heart failure patients @ In cases of high-volume overload such as pulmonary edema or severe peripheral edema, and in the presence of diuretic resistance, consideration may be given to ultrafiltration therapy.
Patients with candidiasis @ For patients who have cystitis and who are allergic to fluconazole, treatment with oral flucytosine, systemic AmB-d, and bladder irrigation with AmB-d are alternatives.

Patients with NSCLC @ For elderly patients, a comprehensive assessment of organ function and ECOG PS status is required. If organ function indicators meet the requirements of chemotherapy, patients with ECOG PS 0−1 can still consider platinum-doublet regimens. Patients with ECOG PS score =2 can consider single-drug chemotherapy. Patients with severe organ dysfunction or ECOG PS score >2 should not be recommended systemic chemotherapy.

triples: organ function indicators meet the requirements of chemotherapy
should not be recommended systemic chemotherapy.

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ Repeated use of antibiotics, such as quinolones, should be avoided if there is no obvious symptomatic benefit from infection control or cultures do not support an infectious cause. Early use of treatments targeting neuropathic pain and/or referral to specialist services should be considered for patients who do not respond to initial measures. An MDT approach is recommended.

triples: no obvious symptomatic benefit from infection control
cultures do not support an infectious cause

text: Infantile cholestasis @ For infants with cholestasis excluding biliary atresia, the recommended treatment for promoting bile flow and resolving jaundice includes ursodeoxycholic acid and other choleretic agents.

triples: promoting bile flow and resolving jaundice

text: Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Colectomy may also be considered in conﬁrmed low-grade dysplasia at repeated occasions or at multiple locations.

triples: at repeated occasions or at multiple locations

text: Patients with NSCLC @ For patients with non-squamous carcinoma, they can be combined with anti-angiogenic therapy such as bevacizumab or endostatin on the basis of chemotherapy; for squamous cell carcinoma, tislelizumab in combination with paclitaxel or sintilimab in combination with gemcitabine platinum-doublet regimen is recommended.
patients with CKD @ For CKD stages 3-5 diabetic patients experiencing high catabolism or protein-energy wasting (PEW), consideration may be given to oral nutritional supplements.
Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ Patients with severe chronic kidney disease stage 4 or above with elderly osteoporosis should avoid the use of bisphosphonates and parathyroid hormone analogs.

triples: severe chronic kidney disease stage 4 or above

text: Patients with achalasia @ Esophagectomy may be needed in those with a dilated esophagus (larger than 8 cm) with poor response to an initial myotomy.

triples: poor response to an initial myotomy

text: Patients with deep vein thrombosis @ Routine use of inferior vena cava filters is not recommended for DVT patients treated with anticoagulation alone.

patients with WPW syndrome @ For patients with supraventricular tachycardia caused by Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, digoxin therapy may be administered in infants and young children under 10 years old. However, adults should not be treated with digoxin.
Patients with NSCLC @ Reoperation is recommended for stage I lung cancer with positive margin. Postoperative radiotherapy is recommended for patients who are unable to reoperation for any reason.

triples: unable to reoperation for any reason

text: Patients with liver cancer @ For patients who cannot be surgically resected, palliative radiotherapy or a combination of radiotherapy and TACE can be used.
Patients with PSC @ Close monitoring and interdisciplinary specialist care is suggested for pregnant women with PSC and cirrhosis, and especially in those with suspected portal hypertension.

Patients with hallux valgus @ When the IMA is less than 13°, distal metatarsal osteotomy along with soft tissue surgery is an option. For IMA in the range of 14° to 16°, procedures such as metatarsal neck (e.g., Scarf) or proximal osteotomy (e.g., modified Ludloff) along with soft tissue surgery can be considered for correction. If IMA is greater than 16°, procedures such as base osteotomy along with soft tissue surgery or Akin surgery may be required.

triples: IMA in the range of 14° to 16°
base osteotomy along with soft tissue surgery

text: Patients with ascites @ Patients experiencing grade 2 (moderate) ascites for the first time should undergo single-agent anti-aldosterone therapy with an initial dose of 100 mg/day. If a low dose shows no response, it should be increased every 72 hours (100 mg/dose) up to a maximum of 400 mg/day. Long-term or recurrent ascites patients should receive combined anti-aldosterone and furosemide therapy.

Patients with oral lichen planus @ For patients with diffuse, stubborn, erosive oral lichen planus or multiple lesions, glucocorticoids such as prednisone (30mg/d) can be administered throughout the body.
Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients with a poor physical condition, advanced age and intolerance to the combined regimen, oral fluorouracil single-drug chemotherapy is considered
Patients with HEV @ For individuals at high risk of HEV infection, vaccination against hepatitis E can be considered.

Patients with G6PD deficiency@chronic patients can use folic acid. Neonates suffering from this disease develop hemolysis and kernicterus, and can be treated with exchange transfusion, phototherapy or phenobarbital injection.

Patients with OSA @ For overweight and obese patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a comprehensive weight loss intervention is recommended, including dietary control, exercise, and behavioral counseling.

Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with mild to moderate hypoxemic respiratory failure, if there are indications for NIPPV but tolerance is poor, nasal high-flow humidified oxygen therapy should be considered.

triples: mild to moderate hypoxemic respiratory failure

text: Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with significant dyspnea accompanied by hypoxemia (SaO2 < 90% or PaO2 < 60 mmHg), oxygen therapy can be administered, such as nasal cannula oxygen and oxygen mask.

Atrial fibrillation patients @ For patients with atrial fibrillation and concurrent heart failure or reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), catheter ablation may be considered when heart failure is related to atrial fibrillation.

Patients with primary liver cancer @ For patients with CNLC stage IIb liver cancer, in most cases, surgical resection is not the preferred initial choice. Instead, non-surgical treatments, mainly TACE, are recommended. Surgical resection may be considered if the tumor is localized within the same segment or half of the liver on one side.

triples: surgical resection is not the preferred initial choice
localized within the same segment or half of the liver on one side

text: Patients with liver cancer @ Patients with hemoglobin levels less than 80g/L may be considered for red blood cell transfusion or drug therapy. Platelet transfusion may be considered in patients with reduced platelet counts.
Patients with DVT @ For patients in the chronic phase of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), it is recommended to administer venous active medications.

triples: chronic phase of deep vein thrombosis

text: Patients with sinusitis @ Perform surgery for cases with nasal deformities of a nasal blockage type.

triples: nasal deformities of a nasal blockage type

text: Patients with AI @ Individuals under the age of 40 or with a history of malignant tumors are at high risk for malignant AI and may consider surgical treatment.

triples: with a history of malignant tumors

text: Patients with MMA and PA @ RANKL-inhibitors (eg, dezotamab) are an option for patients with osteoporosis and relative contraindications (eg, renal failure).
Patients with acute heart failure @ Renal replacement therapy may be indicated for patients with severe hyperkalemia or severe acidosis.

Patients with keloid @ For patients with extremely large keloids who are not suitable for surgery, all are categorized under the principle of non-surgical treatment. Otherwise, for those suitable for surgery, the preferred treatment approach remains surgical intervention supplemented by postoperative radiation and chemotherapy as a comprehensive treatment strategy.
Patients with NSCLC @ For patients with locally advanced NSCLC, concurrent chemoradiation is recommended.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For patients with severe drowsiness, urinary disorders, glaucoma, or asthma, first-generation antihistamines should be avoided.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For severe cases with severe sneezing and rhinorrhea, combine second-generation antihistamine with nasal spray steroids.
Patients with rheumatoid arthritis @ In patients who have contraindications or early intolerance to methotrexate, leflunomide and sulfasalazine are good alternatives

Patients with NSCLC @ For stage I NSCLC patients with contraindications for surgery or refusing surgery due to medical conditions, large fractionation radiotherapy is an effective radical therapy, and SBRT is recommended.

triples: refusing surgery due to medical conditions

text: Patients with candidiasis @ For patients unable to tolerate an oral agent, intravenous fluconazole, an echinocandin, or AmB-d is appropriate.

triples: unable to tolerate an oral agent

text: Patients with keloid @ Non-surgical treatment is recommended for generalized/diffuse keloids.
Patients with inflammatory bowel disease @ Surgery is indicated in patients who have become medically resistant, have intolerable side effects, or presents with life-threatening conditions.

Patients with NSCLC @ The following local treatments are optional for patients unable to undergo surgery or unable to undergo radiotherapy: bronchoscope-mediated laser, high-frequency electrotome, radiofrequency ablation, argon plasma coagulation (APC), microwave, laser.

Patients with liver cancer @ For liver cancer cases where intraoperative exploration reveals that surgical resection is not suitable, intraoperative measures such as catheterization for hepatic artery and portal vein chemotherapy or other local treatment options may be considered.

Patients with chronic diarrhea @ For patients without mental or psychological disorders, if conventional drug therapy does not yield satisfactory results after 4 to 8 weeks, the use of antidepressant medications may be recommended.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Elective TIPS is an effective option for treatment failures/intolerance to secondary prophylaxis of variceal bleeding or in patients with refractory ascites.
CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ Repeated use of antibiotics, such as quinolones, should be avoided where no obvious benefit from infection control is evident or cultures do not support an infective cause.

triples: where no obvious benefit from infection control is evident
cultures do not support an infective cause.

text: Patients with knee osteoarthritis @ Arthroscopic partial meniscectomy can be used for the treatment of meniscal tears in patients with concomitant mild to moderate osteoarthritis who have failed physical therapy or failed other nonsurgical treatments.

Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections @ Empirical treatment for early-stage upper respiratory viral infections may include the use of broad-spectrum alpha interferon through local throat spray. For lower respiratory tract infections, it is recommended to conduct early testing for multiple pathogens.

triples: Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections

text: Patients with viral hepatitis @ In those with eGFR <30, SOF-based regimens  are currently not indicated.

Pregnant patients with acute pulmonary embolism @ For patients without shock or persistent hypotension, low-molecular-weight heparin therapy is recommended, and the dosage should be adjusted according to weight. Generally, monitoring is not necessary, but for patients with extreme weight or kidney disease, anti Xa factor activity should be monitored.

triples: Pregnant patients with acute pulmonary embolism

text: Atrial fibrillation patients @ In patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy complicated by atrial fibrillation, oral anticoagulation should be initiated directly for treatment.

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis @ Rituximab therapy may be considered in patients who have had cancer within the past 5 years, those with a history of lymphoma, those with high-risk tuberculosis, and those with multiple sclerosis.

Patients with hepatolenticular degeneration @ For asymptomatic WD patients identified through screening, early administration of zinc supplements or D-penicillamine for copper chelation can be considered in addition to a low-copper diet.
Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients with posterior gastric wall lesions, postoperative radiotherapy is recommended.

Patients with acute heart failure @ If conventional oxygen therapy is unsatisfactory, or if the respiratory rate is > 25 breaths/min and SpO2 is < 90%, non-invasive positive pressure ventilation should be initiated promptly.
Patients with simple hallux valgus @ For mismatched joints, consider Silver soft tissue surgery first. For matched joints, proceed with a corrective DMAA procedure.

Patients with achalasia @ After surgery, if the patient has a mild pneumothorax with lung compression volume less than 30%, stable breathing, and blood oxygen saturation greater than 95%, special treatment is usually not required; for pneumothorax with lung compression volume exceeding 30%, thoracentesis is feasible Closed drainage.

triples: mild pneumothorax with lung compression volume less than 30%
special treatment is usually not required

text: Patients with hallux valgus @ For middle-aged to elderly patients with mild to moderately displaced thumb arthritis, recommending arthroplasty surgery is appropriate.

triples: mild to moderately displaced thumb arthritis

text: Patients with chronic pancreatitis @ For patients with severe malnutrition, insulin therapy is the preferred choice.

heart failure patients @ For patients with severe hyponatremia (serum sodium <130mmol/L), water intake should be restricted to less than 2 L/day. In cases of severe heart failure accompanied by significant wasting (cardiac cachexia), nutritional support should be provided.

triples: water intake should be restricted to less than 2 L/day

text: Patients with thyroid carcinoma @ Thyroid nodules with diameter >1 cm and more than one malignant ultrasound signs, are recommended for US-FNAB. US-FNAB is not recommended for thyroid nodules with diameter ≤1 cm, unless the following conditions: A) abnormal cervical lymph nodes observed;

triples: more than one malignant ultrasound signs

text: Patients with breast cancer @ For high-risk premenopausal patients, if the patient remains premenopausal after 5 years of tamoxifen, tamoxifen to 10 years may be considered. If the patient becomes postmenopausal during tamoxifen treatment, aromatase inhibitor for another 5 years after 5 years of tamoxifen may be considered.
bladder cancer patients @ For patients with refractory hematuria in bladder cancer, palliative cystectomy and urinary diversion are effective treatment options.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Low-to-medium-dose UDCA (10-15 mg/kg/d) can be given in patients with ABCB4 deﬁciency。

Patients with ABP @ Patients with ABP and concomitant extrahepatic biliary obstruction may be considered for treatment with local anesthesia under percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage or percutaneous transhepatic bile duct drainage.
Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ For patients with an insufficient response to UDCA, adding a second-line therapy such as obeticholic acid, fibrates, and budesonide can be considered.

Patients with autoimmune hepatitis @ Therefore, as a first-line treatment, budesonide and AZA combination therapy can be selectively considered in patients with autoimmune hepatitis without cirrhosis who are highly likely to have glucocorticoid-induced adverse effects, or when prednisolone administration is not possible due to adverse effects.

triples: when prednisolone administration is not possible due to adverse effects.

text: Patients with malignant gastric obstruction @ For patients with mid-gastric obstruction or distal gastric obstruction who are unable to eat, a jejunal feeding tube can be placed.

patients with aortic stenosis @ If a patient with aortic valve stenosis experiences symptoms such as shortness of breath, angina, or fainting during exertion, or if there is evidence of left ventricular failure, surgical replacement of the diseased valve is recommended.

triples: surgical replacement of the diseased valve

text: Patients with WD @ For WD patients with varying degrees of liver damage, neurological or psychiatric symptoms, and those allergic or intolerant to D-penicillamine, dithio-dimercaptosuccinic acid may be used in combination with zinc supplementation for treatment.

Patients with thrombocytopenia in cancer patients with liver injury @ For patients with severe splenic hyperfunction/splenomegaly, invasive treatments such as splenic embolization or splenectomy may be considered. In cases where invasive treatments are contraindicated, treatment with recombinant human thrombopoietin or thrombopoietin receptor agonists may be considered.

triples: Patients with thrombocytopenia in cancer patients with liver injury

text: Patient with gastric cancer @ For the patients with an allergy to β-lactamase, clindamycin + aminoglycosides can be recommended.
Patients with cirrhosis @ For acute variceal bleeding patients with hepatic venous pressure gradient ≥20 mmHg, early transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt is recommended.
Patients with NSCLC @ For airway stenosis and airway fistula that cannot be relieved by conventional treatment, internal stent implantation should be considered as the main treatment.

triples: cannot be relieved by conventional treatment

text: Patients with PSC @ Therapeutic endoscopic intervention is recommended in children with high-grade strictures on imaging and signs or symptoms of obstructive cholestasis or bacterial cholangitis.
Patients with acute heart failure @ For patients with refractory volume overload and poor diuretic response, ultrafiltration therapy can be considered.
Patients with PVT @ For patients with acute PVT, anticoagulant therapy is recommended if there is acute complete thrombosis of the main portal vein.

triples: acute complete thrombosis of the main portal vein

text: Patients with primary liver cancer @ For patients with CNLC stage IIIb liver cancer accompanied by metastasis to the hepatic hilar lymph nodes, consideration may be given to tumor resection along with hepatic hilar lymph node dissection or postoperative external beam radiotherapy.

triples: metastasis to the hepatic hilar lymph nodes

text: Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ UDCA at 13-15 mg/kg/d for life-long is a standard therapy for all PBC patients. OCA at a dose of 5-10 mg/d is recommended for patients with suboptimal biochemical response to UDCA.
Patients with acute hepatitis @ Patients with cholestasis can use ursodeoxycholic acid, etc.
Patients with CP @ For patients with painful chronic pancreatitis accompanied by pancreatic duct dilation and no complications, endoscopic therapy is often the preferred initial treatment.

Patients with AI @ For patients with fewer risk factors for malignant adrenal incidentalomas, surgical resection is recommended if during follow-up, the maximum diameter increases by more than 20% and increases by >5 mm, or if there are clinical manifestations of malignant tumors (such as cachexia) or imaging features, or hormonal secretion abnormalities. If no abnormalities are observed during follow-up for 2 to 5 years, it is advisable to reduce the frequency of follow-up until discontinuation.

triples: fewer risk factors for malignant adrenal incidentalomas
the maximum diameter increases by more than 20%
reduce the frequency of follow-up until discontinuation

text: Patients with CRC @ For postoperative CRC patients with malnutrition, it is recommended to continue nutritional therapy for 4 to 8 weeks after discharge. Standard formula oral nutritional supplements (ONS) are recommended during this period.

Patients with keloid @ For scars with a diameter <1.5 cm, a comprehensive treatment approach may include intralesional corticosteroid injections, along with silicone products, scar-reducing topical medications, and compression therapy. If the keloid is larger than 2.0 cm and exhibits a persistent growth trend, consideration may be given to the partial excision of the keloid followed by wound closure.

triples: the keloid is larger than 2.0 cm

text: Patients with OSA @ Oral appliance treatment is suitable for patients with simple snoring and mild to moderate OSA.

Patient with gastric cancer @ For primary tumors or metastatic tumors, gastrectomy combined with resection of involved organs can be used to achieve cure. If the tumor is located in the greater curvature and is not metastatic, lymphadenectomy and total gastrectomy and splenectomy should be considered. In other cases, prophylactic splenectomy is not recommended unless the tumor directly invades the spleen.

triples: tumor is located in the greater curvature

text: Mitral valve stenosis patients @ Asymptomatic patients with mitral stenosis do not require treatment, but long-term antibiotic prophylaxis may be needed to prevent future episodes of rheumatic fever. Symptomatic patients may be treated with diuretics and β-blockers or calcium channel blockers.

Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ For patients who have good compliance, giving alendronate sodium can effectively improve the bone density of the lumbar spine, femoral neck and total hip; for patients who cannot take it orally or have poor compliance, zoledronic acid can be chosen.

triples: take it orally and have good compliance

text: Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ We suggest consideration of TIF for patients with troublesome regurgitation or heartburn who do not wish to undergo antireflux surgery and who do not have severe reflux esophagitis (LA grade C or D) or hiatal hernias >2 cm.

triples: do not wish to undergo antireflux surgery
do not have severe reflux esophagitis

text: Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For symptoms of sneezing and rhinorrhea type, use a combination of nasal topical steroids and second-generation antihistamine. For symptoms of the nasal blockage type and those of combined type, add leukotriene receptor antagonists or a prostaglandin D2 / thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist.

triples: symptoms of the nasal blockage type

text: Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ We recommend consideration of MSA as an alternative to laparoscopic fundoplication for patients with regurgitation who fail medical management.

Patients with liver cancer @ Liver cancer patients often have complications such as cirrhosis and splenomegaly. Consideration may be given to blood product transfusions or drug therapy. In patients with neutropenia, granulocyte colony-stimulating factor may be administered as appropriate.
Patients with PVT @ For patients with chronic PVT, if there is a genetic or acquired predisposition to thrombosis, anticoagulant therapy is recommended.

Patients with NSCLC @ If the physical conditions permit, conformal radiotherapy combined with concurrent chemotherapy should be used in patients with stage II−III NSCLC who are unable to undergo surgery for physical reasons.

triples: unable to undergo surgery for physical reasons

text: Patients with ascites @ Patients with bacterial peritonitis showing systemic inflammation or signs of infection should receive antibiotic therapy. Otherwise, a second abdominal paracentesis is required.

Patients with liver failure @ When blood ammonia levels are significantly elevated or accompanied by hepatic encephalopathy, protein intake should be reduced to 1g/kg/d. Oral lactulose or high enema should be administered to promote bowel movements. If these measures are ineffective or if blood ammonia levels remain severely elevated, blood purification therapy should be considered.

triples: blood ammonia levels are significantly elevated

text: Patients with hallux valgus @ When the IMA is greater than 20°, and there is a semi-dislocation of the proximal phalanx base relative to the metatarsal head exceeding 50%, along with significant soft tissue contracture, the preferred recommendation is tarsometatarsal joint fusion surgery.

triples: semi-dislocation of the proximal phalanx base relative to the metatarsal head exceeding 50%

text: Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia @ HoLEP, PVP, and ThuLEP should be considered as treatment options in patients who are at higher risk of bleeding.

Patients with oral lichen planus @ For patients with oral lichen planus who do not respond well to topical corticosteroids, it is recommended to use calcineurin inhibitors such as tacrolimus and pimecrolimus, twice daily, as needed for 4 to 6 weeks.

triples: do not respond well to topical corticosteroids

text: Patients with knee osteoarthritis @ Sustained weight loss is recommended to improve pain and function in overweight and obese patients with knee osteoarthritis.
Patients with ascites @ Large Volume Paracentesis (LVP) is the primary treatment for patients with significant or severe ascites, and it involves removing all ascitic fluid at once.

triples: removing all ascitic fluid at once

text: Children with recurrent respiratory tract infections @ If the patient experiences mild cough, you may consider oral traditional Chinese medicine with lung-ventilating and cough-suppressing effects, such as Children's Cough Granules. For severe cough, combination with bronchodilators is advisable.

text: Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For intractable rhinorrhea, perform posterior nasal neurectomy.

Patients with CKD @ For patients with CKD and co-infection of HBV/HCV, if HBsAG is positive, it is recommended to initiate a combination therapy with entecavir or tenofovir during and three months after DAA treatment. If HBsAG is negative but anti-HBc is positive, monitoring of HBsAG and HBV DNA is advised during and three months after the treatment (2C).

triples: monitoring of HBsAG and HBV DNA

text: Children with onychomycosis@if the weight is <20kg, take terbinafine 62.5mg/d orally; if the weight is 20~40kg, take terbinafine 125mg/d orally.

Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients with physical condition score ECOG≥2, fourth-line chemotherapy, unresectable primary gastric lesions, poor bone marrow functional reserve, and old and weak or thin female patients, to ensure the safety of patients and improve compliance, oral apatinib can be started from a low dose.

Patients with SAP @ For hemodynamically stable patients, options include intermittent hemodialysis, blood perfusion adsorption, or plasma perfusion adsorption as blood purification modes. For hemodynamically unstable patients, CRRT may be chosen.

Patients with hepatic hydatid disease @ For cases where a curative effect can be achieved through surgical means, radical methods should be considered whenever possible. In patients with hepatic hydatid disease for whom surgery cannot achieve a cure, if the patient is asymptomatic, surgical treatment should not be considered. Instead, drug therapy should be chosen to control the progression of the disease.

triples: curative effect can be achieved through surgical means

text: Raynaud's disease patients @ For patients with recurrent attacks and severe symptoms but no fingertip atrophy, calcium channel blockers can be used. For patients with recurrent attacks of fingertip atrophy but no open ulcers, in addition to calcium channel blockers, drugs that affect sympathetic nerve activity can be added. For patients with recurrent attacks of severe ischemia, cyan skin, and open fingertip ulcers, intravenous infusion of the vasodilator prostaglandins can be used.

triples: drugs that affect sympathetic nerve activity

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ In patients with early‐stage CBP or CP/CPPS, use of opioids for pain management should be avoided, due to the risk of drug dependency.

Patients with gastroenteritis @ Mild dehydration can be treated with oral glucose electrolyte solutions and broth.. In cases of severe dehydration, isotonic intravenous fluids such as lactated Ringer's solution and normal saline should be administered.
Patients with cholestatic hepatitis E @ For those with severe bile stasis, the consideration of using glucocorticoids might be beneficial.
Patient with gastric cancer @ If the patient undergoes gastric cancer surgery with a type II incision, it is recommended to use prophylactic antibiotics.

triples: gastric cancer surgery with a type II incision

text: Patients with adrenal accidental tumor @ Surgical intervention is recommended for adrenal incidentalomas with a nodule CT attenuation value >20 Hounsfield Units (HU) and evidence of malignant characteristics.

triples: nodule CT attenuation value >20 Hounsfield Units

text: Patients with MSAP/SAP @ For patients predicted to have MSAP/SAP with severe pain and concomitant cardiovascular or respiratory failure, epidural analgesia may be considered.
Patients with inflammatory bowel disease @ Oral 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is the standard therapy for mild to moderately active IBD.

CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ In patients describing typical neuropathic pain symptoms (e.g. ‘burning’, ‘shooting’ pain), or in any patient with persistent pain (>3 months), treat with appropriate anti‐neuropathic medication strategies.
Patients with viral hepatitis @ For those with genotype 1 or 4 infection, options for therapy include  glecaprevir、pibrentasvir、sofosbuvir、ledipasvir

Patients with keloid @ For patients with extremely large keloids who have contraindications such as diabetes, hypertension, endocrine disorders, or severe post-injection acne on the face (contraindications to corticosteroid injections), considering the use of isolated 5-FU injections along with laser therapy, silicone preparations, topical medications, and compression therapy may be an alternative treatment approach.

triples: severe post-injection acne on the face

text: Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For symptoms of nasal blockage or combined type, add nasal topical steroids with leukotriene receptor antagonists or prostaglandin D2/thromboxane A2 receptor antagonists.
Patients with rheumatoid arthritis @ Follow-up evaluations and treatment adjustments are in order in patients who fail to improve within 3 months or to achieve their treatment target within 6 months.

triples: fail to achieve their treatment target within 6 months

text: Patients with AI @ For patients determined to have bilateral secretion through AVS, surgery may be considered if they experience drug-related side effects or have difficulty maintaining long-term control of hypertension and hypokalemia with internal medicine treatment. triples: have difficulty maintaining long-term control of hypokalemia

text: Patients with rotavirus gastroenteritis @ In cases of severe dehydration, shock, altered mental status, or failure of oral rehydration therapy, or in the presence of intestinal obstruction, isotonic intravenous fluids such as lactated Ringer's solution and normal saline should be administered.
Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients with early detection of precancerous lesions, traditional Chinese medicine treatment can be selected, such as adjusting diet and adjusting lifestyle.
Patients with MUTYH polyposis syndrome @ Surgery may be required for removal if there is cancer or if the burden of polyps is too significant.

text: Patients with AAH @ In highly selected patients with severe AAH not responding to optimal medical therapy and supportive measures, LT may beconsidered

text: Patients with PVT @ For patients with non-cirrhotic, acute symptomatic PVT without contraindications, anticoagulant therapy is recommended as the first-line treatment.

Patients with liver cancer @ For 2-3 tumors located in different regions, or tumors situated deep within the liver or in a central location, a combination of ablation therapy and surgical resection can be considered.

triples: tumors situated deep within the liver or in a central location

text: Patients with DILI @ For mild to moderate hepatocellular and mixed-type Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI), individuals with mild inflammation may consider using silymarin at a dose of 140 mg per administration, three times daily. For those with more severe inflammation, formulations containing glycyrrhizic acid could be considered.
Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients who develop respiratory infections after surgery, antibiotics can be used to treat them.
Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ For patients with mild GERD, medication can be reduced, but patients with severe reflux esophagitis will require long-term PPI therapy.

Patients with Candida infection of the cardiovascular system @ Candida infections of the cardiovascular system @ For patients who cannot undergo valve replacement, long-term suppression with fluconazole at a dosage of 400-800 mg daily is recommended

triples: Patients with Candida infection of the cardiovascular system
Patients with Candida infection of the cardiovascular system

text: Patient with gastric cancer @ Consider single-agent chemotherapy with oral fluorouracils or taxanes for patients with poor performance status and advanced age. For patients with gastric cancer with positive HER2 expression, the molecular targeted therapy drug trastuzumab combined with chemotherapy can be used. Apatinib alone may be considered for patients with advanced gastric cancer who have failed 2 previous chemotherapy regimens and are in good physical condition.

Patients with DILI @ Liver transplantation should be included in the treatment options for cases judged to be severe in a severity assessment. Special treatments such as corticosteroid pulse therapy and liver supporting therapies may also be effective.

Patients with HEV @ During the early stage of acute HEV infection, it's advisable for the patient to observe home isolation or be hospitalized. Bed rest is recommended during this period, and gradual increases in activity can be initiated during the recovery phase.

Patients with ascites @ For patients with refractory ascites where sodium excretion is less than 30 mmol/d despite diuretic therapy, discontinuation of diuretics is recommended. TIPS treatment is recommended for refractory ascites patients as it can improve the control of ascites.

triples: sodium excretion is less than 30 mmol/d despite diuretic therapy

text: Patients with NSCLC @ For NSCLC patients who undergo surgery, if the pathology of surgical margin is negative and the mediastinal lymph node is positive (pN2 stage), besides routine postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy, adjuvant radiotherapy can be used, and chemotherapy followed by sequential radiotherapy is recommended.

triples: pathology of surgical margin is negative

text: Patients with breast cancer @ Neoadjuvant therapy with taxanes alone plus platinum may be considered for patients with underlying cardiac disease.

Patients with gastroenteritis @ If vomiting is severe and non-surgical acute abdomen (such as intestinal obstruction) has been ruled out, antiemetic drugs may be effective. Ondansetron can be administered orally or intravenously in adults and children. The oral and intravenous doses for adults are 4 or 8 mg, three or four times a day. The intravenous dose for children is 0.15 or 0.3 mg/kg. Additionally, adults can use prochlorperazine and promethazine medications.

triples: three or four times a day

text: Patients with knee osteoarthritis @ Topical NSAIDs should be used to improve function and quality of life for treatment of osteoarthritis of the knee, when not contraindicated.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For cases of nasal blockage type, in which the effects of pharmacotherapy are insufficient, surgical treatment can also be chosen.

triples: the effects of pharmacotherapy are insufficient

text: Patients with OMM @ Cryotherapy can be employed as a palliative measure for tumor reduction in patients at intermediate to advanced stages.

Patients with post-thrombotic syndrome @ For patients who are younger, have a longer life expectancy, and have mild Villalta scores or moderate Villalta scores, conservative treatment is mainly used. Patients with severe Villalta score or venous ulcers, common femoral vein stenosis or occlusion can be treated with endovascular intervention.
Patients with ALF @ Liver transplantation can be considered for ALF with manifestations such as hepatic encephalopathy and severe coagulation disorders.

Patients with acute bacterial sinusitis @ Intravenous antibiotics may be considered in children who cannot tolerate oral medications for ABRS or in those with orbital, subperiosteal, or epidural abscesses.

triples: cannot tolerate oral medications for ABRS

text: heart failure patients @ Nitroprusside is suitable for patients with severe heart failure, increased afterload, and those with pulmonary congestion or pulmonary edema.

Patients with insulinoma @ For multiple adenomas in the body or tail of the pancreas, distal pancreatectomy can be performed. In the case of malignant insulinoma in the proximal pancreas amenable to resection, a pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) is indicated. In patients with incomplete prior distal pancreatectomy, complete pancreatectomy may be considered.

triples: multiple adenomas in the body or tail of the pancreas
malignant insulinoma in the proximal pancreas amenable to resection

text: Hypertensive patients @ Recommend weight loss for overweight hypertensive patients. For patients with obesity, diabetes, or high cholesterol levels, consider dietary changes such as increased consumption of fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products.

triples: increased consumption of fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products

text: Patients with NSCLC @ Immune checkpoint inhibitors can be considered for NSCLC patients who fail to respond to platinum-doublet chemotherapy or targeted therapy.

triples: fail to respond to platinum-doublet chemotherapy
fail to respond to targeted therapy

text: Patients with HEV @ Patients with unexplained ALT abnormalities or clinical symptoms of hepatitis should undergo testing for anti-HEV IgM and anti-HEV IgG. For immunocompromised patients, additional testing for HEV RNA or antigen is recommended.

triples: testing for HEV RNA or antigen

text: Patient with gastric cancer @ For elderly patients with poor physical condition, severe illness, and inability to tolerate Western medicine treatment, traditional Chinese medicine treatment can be used as an auxiliary treatment.

triples: inability to tolerate Western medicine treatment

text: Patients with cirrhosis and ascites @ For patients with moderate to large-volume ascites, recurrent ascites, and hyponatremia, when conventional diuretic therapy is ineffective, it is recommended to use the selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist tolvaptan as a treatment option.
Patients with GSDIa @ For patients with renal impairment, combined liver and kidney transplantation can be performed.
Patients with PSC @ For PSC patients with dominant bile duct strictures, endoscopic balloon dilation or short-term stent placement can be performed for biliary drainage treatment.

Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ Adequate intake of calcium and vitamin D is crucial for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis. For adults over 50 years old who are at moderate risk for vitamin D deficiency, the recommended daily intake of vitamin D is 800 to 1000 IU; consider those aged 60 and above The above-mentioned elderly people often suffer from vitamin D deficiency due to lack of sunshine and impaired intake and absorption. The recommended calcium intake for the elderly and elderly patients with osteoporosis is 1000-1200 mg/d, and the vitamin D3 intake is 800~1200 IU/d.

triples: moderate risk for vitamin D deficiency

text: Patients with WD @ Sodium 2-mercaptoethanesulfonate is suitable for severe WD patients and those with neurological or psychiatric symptoms. The adult dose is 500 to 750 mg once daily, and the pediatric dose is 10 to 20 mg/(kg·d).

Patients with sarcoidosis and tuberculosis @ For patients with mild symptoms, stable condition, no significant organ involvement, and no need for prioritized treatment of nodules, it is advisable to prioritize diagnostic anti-tuberculosis therapy.

triples: no need for prioritized treatment of nodules

text: Patients with COVID-19 @ For patients with lingering cough symptoms following the resolution of acute symptoms of COVID-19, short-term use of cough suppressants is recommended. The use of antibiotics or inhaled corticosteroids is not advised.
Patients with liver cancer @ If HBsAg is positive, it is recommended to use potent and low-resistance drugs such as entecavir, tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, or tenofovir alafenamide.

Streptococcus pneumoniae pneumonia patients @ Supportive therapy: For severe chest pain, a small amount of analgesics may be used. Do not use aspirin or other antipyretics to avoid excessive sweating, dehydration and interference with the true heat pattern, leading to incorrect clinical judgment. Moderately or severely ill patients should be given oxygen.
Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ For those with portal hypertension, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy can be performed in the second trimester.

Hypoparathyroidism patients @ For patients with recurrent and difficult-to-relieve symptoms, continuous intravenous infusion of calcium can be administered, supplementing approximately 500-1,000 mg of elemental calcium per day. In cases of severe attacks, short-term muscle injections of diazepam or phenytoin may be used.

Patients with vaginal laxity syndrome @ If a patient lacks columnar folds and does not have specific defects in a particular area, for those with congenital vaginal wall prolapse into the boat-shaped fossa, performing distal vaginal excision and hymenorrhaphy reconstruction may be considered.

triples: congenital vaginal wall prolapse into the boat-shaped fossa
